div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
THIS is not de≈øigned for thy hand before the Peru≈øal of a little Book, with a great Name, viz. Novum Lumen Chirurgicum: I ≈øhall not much quarrel about the Name, nor u≈øe any ≈øini≈øter Endeavours to obnubilate this pretended Luminary, other than by an impartial Examen with how much Ju≈øtice it's intitled to ≈øuch a Name, or the Author to ≈øuch large and ≈øpecious Preten≈øions equally famous for nothing el≈øe: But I am willing to believe the Name was given
at the Bookseller's Reque≈øt, for a Set-of to the Merchandize, there being little hopes of a Second Impre≈ø≈øion. However, he gives thee a large Account of the hearty and vigorous Pro≈øecution of his Studies, for no le≈øs than ≈øeven Years, in order to his Attainment of this famous Nothing, and I hope will give us leave to ≈øay, Parturiunt montes, na≈øcetur ridiculus mus.

Neverthele≈øs, if the Pretence of a good Intention be meritorious to the Ju≈øtification of a World of ∆≤ntruths, here is one of a thou≈øand; viz. the Relief of tho≈øe Worthies who from a Principle of Love and Bravery, are daily expo≈øing their Lives for the Service of their King and Country; who before the finding out of his Medicines (though but ≈øcratch'd with the Point of a Bodkin) were always irrecoverably lo≈øt.

His fir≈øt Experiments were upon Dogs, and ≈øuch like; and I do verily believe it had been a ≈øingular Kindne≈øs done the World never to have rai≈øed them higher, tho≈øe Animals being but too too good Subjects for ≈øuch an Operator. He ≈øays he had above an hundred of them, and wounded them all de≈øperately. I am fully ≈øatisfied they all died ≈øave one, who had his Leg cut off.

As for tho≈øe three Experiments made before my Lord Cutts, I ≈øhall give thee the Relation of Matter of Fact from a Per≈øon of both undoubted Honour and Ingenuity, viz. Lieutenant Colonel Newton, then Lieutenant Colonel to my Lord: With whom I being in Company one day in Southwark, ≈øome few days after the Trial of the≈øe Experiments, I de≈øired him to give me ≈øuch Account of that Matter as I might depend
upon: He told me him≈øelf had been pre≈øent at them, and that two of the three were already dead; but that the Doctor (as he called him) told him the third was alive, though run away; however, he believed him to have accompanied the re≈øt, and likewi≈øe told the Doctor that it was like to prove a fatal Campagne for Brutes, but hoped it would be a better for Mankind. He withal told me, that my Lord was ≈øufficiently weary of his Experiments, and believed he would take no farther notice of him: As for the Souldier, all that knew his Condition, believed his greate≈øt Danger to con≈øi≈øt in that of his having fallen into ≈øuch Hands, whatever Excu≈øe he is able to coin to the contrary.

I believe he ≈øpeaks true in ≈øaying, that his Failing in his Preten≈øions was the Cau≈øe why his Maje≈øty did not
then imploy him. I am ≈øure if he be right informed, he hath the ≈øame or more ≈øtill.

He ≈øays of all the Patients he had in Flanders, there was but one died. And truly that was no great Wonder, con≈øidering the Smalne≈øs of their Number: however, perhaps it may be found to be a Mi≈øtake by and by.

I am ≈øo far from doubting the Truth of Mr. Cowper's Di≈øcovering his External Medicine to be a con≈øiderable Cau≈øtick, that I am able to demon≈øtrate it again≈øt all Oppo≈øition; for until by its frequent Application there be a Cru≈øt or E≈øchare induced upon the Part, his Patients never fail to complain of intolerable gnawing Pains: By which he fearing his Medicine's falling into Di≈øgrace, was generally obliged to allay its Sharpne≈øs by a little Smart-Money, as we ≈øhall hear by and by.

In his next Paragraph he ≈øays, his Medicines cure all Wounds without Suppuration; but Suppuration once begun, they are incomparable Dige≈øtives. But this is no more than one of his accu≈øtomed Contradictions, in ≈øaying, that a thing is the mo≈øt improper, and yet the mo≈øt proper for producing the ≈øame effect.

As for his treating of Gun-≈øhot Wounds where the Bones are ≈øhattered, he ≈øays, by his Method, the bringing away of the Splinters is neither hazardous nor trouble≈øom. By which I under≈øtand he is changeable in his Opinion; for my ≈øelf, and ≈øeveral others not long ≈øince, have heard him affirm, that there was no Occa≈øion for the Removal of any ≈øuch Splinters; for that by Virtue of his Medicine, he could bring them to a Reunion in a very
≈ømall time. But his ninth Experiment ≈øeems to have taught him more Wit: He ≈øays he might have enlarged the Number of his Experiments: And truly ≈øo he might, with the ≈øame Ju≈øtice he hath u≈øed them, as we ≈øhall ≈øee hereafter. As for his Stopping great Fluxes of Blood, we ≈øhall refer him to his thirteeenth Experiment.

But as for his being poi≈øoned, I could never find even his be≈øt Friends inclinable to give any Credit to it, further than believing him (by a Mi≈øtake) to have upon a certain time taken ≈øome of his own Tincture, for the trial of an Experiment; and it's very probable that his two Friends might be as ignorant as him≈øelf: however, it is certain that it is capable to produce all tho≈øe Symptoms of Poi≈øoning, which either him≈øelf or his Friends pretended to have. Nor was it at all likely that any Per≈øon
(how wicked ≈øoever) ≈øhould either trouble or hazard them≈øelves by ≈øuch an Action, con≈øidering that any one (though never ≈øo ≈øhort-≈øighted) mu≈øt needs di≈øcover the Period of his already expiring Preten≈øions: Neverthele≈øs, him≈øelf cannot di≈øown his having very ill de≈øerved of ≈øeveral, or almo≈øt all Per≈øons of that Profe≈ø≈øion. For in≈øtance; A Souldier in the Engli≈øh Guards having received a con≈øiderable Wound in the Brea≈øt, his Officer ≈øent for Mr. Colbatch: But in the interim, Mr. Harris, Chirurgion to the Regiment, came and dre≈ø≈øed the Patient after the u≈øual Method. Soon after Mr. Colbatch came; who without any regard to the former Dre≈ø≈øing, was going to make his Application. But not being ≈øuffered by Mr. Harris, he went away and maliciou≈øly reported to many Per≈øons in the Camp, that the Man was dead for want of his Application: Be≈øides others, he reported
this to the Major and two Captains of the Fu≈øileers; who ≈øending next Morning to inform them≈øelves of the Truth, were ≈øatisfied to his no ≈ømall Di≈øgrace, that the Souldier had not only e≈øcaped all Danger of Death, but even that of his Hands: But this is but one of many.

The Rea≈øon, as he ≈øaith, why he hath u≈øed ≈øo few Terms of Art, is, becau≈øe he de≈øigns Plainne≈øs; but I ≈øay it is, becau≈øe he had none, except he hath very lately got them. In my Opinion he is very excu≈øable in not mentioning what his Medicines are, becau≈øe the Knowledg of them would not only derogate from their Reputation, which is principally ≈øupported by this Secrecy, but al≈øo impede their Vending, which is the Author's chief De≈øign.

Now at la≈øt he is de≈øigned to give the World an extraordinary Ta≈øte of his Mode≈øty and Civility, in vouch≈øafing to rank him≈øelf amongst ≈øuch Per≈øons as Helmont, Willis, Needham; and does tell us, that his Authority is no le≈øs ≈øufficient to recommend a Medicine (though unknown to the World, and even him≈øelf too) than any of theirs was.

div.head: Novum Lumen Chirurgicum extinctum.
div.p:
THE far greater Part of this Treati≈øe (which I am now about to make ≈øome Remarks upon) ≈øeems rather de≈øigned for the Amu≈øement of the unthinking Reader, and ≈øwelling of the Book to ≈øuch a convenient Bulk, as may in ≈øome mea≈øure conceal the Defect and Barrenne≈øs of its Author's Inventions, than either the ≈øupport of an old, or the laying down of any new Hypothe≈øis; which though he readily promi≈øes, he no where performs that which he pretends to, being no more than an incoherent, incon≈øi≈øtent, mangled, nay even murdred
Parcel of Collections, and many of tho≈øe neither from the fir≈øt nor be≈øt hands.

After ≈øome, as ≈øilly as impertinent Reflections upon Surgeons and their Methods, &c. he ≈øays, that his pre≈øent Undertaking will be altogether maimed and imperfect, without giving us fir≈øt ≈øome Account of Nutrition; and truly I may ≈øay ≈øo it is with it.
At fir≈øt glance I expected he would begin with the Nutrition of a Foetus in the Womb; but I doubt he was afraid of an Abortion, which hath made him change his Subject into that of an Adult.
in his 3d and 5th Pages he goes on with this Account, without the lea≈øt mentioning any of tho≈øe Authors Names from whom he ≈øtole it.

In his 6th and 7th Pages, he talks confu≈øedly of Fire in the Blood, and ≈øeems to incline ≈øomewhat to the Belief of it; but not daring to allow it
either Wood, Turff, or Sea-Coal, is not a little troubled to find a Pabulum for it.

In his 8th and 9th Pages, he hath taken too much pains in making and an≈øwering an Objection, which mu≈øt by and by fall together. For if by Matter he means that which is ≈øuppurated from Wounds, the Objection is altogether fal≈øe; for ≈øo ≈øoon as a Wound begins to matter, the Fever for the mo≈øt pa≈øt remits. If this be not his Meaning, I doubt neither of us know it. He ≈øeems likewi≈øe at no ≈ømall lo≈øs about the Rea≈øons of ≈øo great and ≈øudden Wa≈øte made upon fat Per≈øons by violent Fevers, if there be no Flame in the Blood: but that proceeds from his Ignorance of the Animal Oeconomy, together with his Forgetfulne≈øs of Sanctorius's Experiment, which him≈øelf is to mention by and by.
In the 10th he goes on with his Story, more confu≈øed than the Liquor he is there plea≈øed to term ≈øo.

But I cannot omit taking notice of his Civility to Sanctorius in his 11th Page, in allowing him the Honour of his own Ob≈øervation, becau≈øe it is more than he hath done to any other Per≈øon hitherto in all his Account, either of Sanguification or Nutrition, though it be all at be≈øt but borrowed, and much of it at ≈øecond hand.

In his 12th he carries on his Conjecture of Nutrition by the Serum; but hath borrowed ≈øo much Mode≈øty as to own his Ignorance of Nature's adapting the Pores and Particles to each other for that Purpo≈øe; by which Means he hath ≈øaved me the labour of doing it for him.

His 13th, 14th and 15th, are taken up with Three Experiments, which he brings for the Proof of all Vegetables being nouri≈øhed by Water only: the fir≈øt ≈øeems to be from ≈øome Hone≈øt Gardiner, the ≈øecond is Helmont's, and the third the Famous Boyle's.
I am fully ≈øatisfied they are the true≈øt and be≈øt part of his Book; and therefore ≈øhall neither repeat nor quarrel at them, they being already ≈øufficiently injured by coming thro' his hands.

In his 16th, when the danger is almo≈øt over, he is fallen into an inextricable Difficulty; which ≈øince him≈øelf pretends no where to remove, I hope will have the Patience to ≈øee the total Subver≈øion and utter Ruine of his ill built, and wor≈øe ≈øupported Hypothe≈øis.

The Difficulty is this; That notwith≈øtanding all Vegetables have their Nutrition and Increa≈øe from Water only, do neverthele≈øs afford us ≈øuch Sub≈øtances as are neither ea≈øily mixed with, nor indeed obtainable from Water.

In his 17th Page he ≈øays, that he thinks there is no Difference, only ≈øecundum Majus & Minus, between tho≈øe Wa≈øtes made by in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration
which are natural, and a Wound made by Force which is preternatural. Had he not ≈øaid he thought, I ≈øhould have thought he ≈øpoke ironically, meaning all the Difference in the World: I am ≈øure I think ≈øo, for

Fir≈øt, There is a material Difference; that which we wa≈øte by in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration being thin, volatile and excrementitious; but this which Nature doth ≈øupply for the re-union of a divided Sub≈øtance, a Juice Bal≈øamick fixed, and nece≈ø≈øary.
Secondly, There is a formal Difference: for,

In in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration the Effluvia can make no Digre≈ø≈øion in their Pa≈ø≈øage along the Fibres, until they e≈øcape by the Pores of the Cuticle; but in a Wound the mentioned Juice drilling along the Fibres after its accu≈øtomed manner, until it comes to the Divi≈øion, where it immediately drops down, without ≈øome previous
Information from his Almighty Pouder.
But now he ≈øeems to de≈øign ≈øome faint Approaches to the Matter: he ≈øuppo≈øes a Wound to be made, &c.
But here are ≈øo many ≈øuppo≈øitions, that they require to be ≈øummed up together:
In the 17th, When there is a Divi≈øion made.
In the 18th, Suppo≈øe a Divi≈øion to be made, and it's no matter where.
In the ≈øame Page, Now let a Wound be made where it will, and how, it matters not.
Now in the 20th, we are come to the fourth, and I hope la≈øt Suppo≈øition: for the other three have been very u≈øele≈øs and impertinent.
He ≈øays, Let a Divi≈øion be made in any of the Parts of the Body, which we call a Wound; and how it's made it matters not, &c.

The nutritious Juice is immediately brought to the Ends of the wounded Ve≈ø≈øels: For their Reparation and Reunion, which (as he ≈øays) would ≈øoon be effected were not Nature oppre≈ø≈øed, and her regular Operations impeded, by the common Methods and Medicines of Chirurgions.

Now although almo≈øt every Page be larded with ≈øuch groundle≈øs A≈øper≈øions upon Chirurgions and their Medicines, I ≈øhall this once for all, a little weigh and con≈øider the Rea≈øons which he hath brought again≈øt the common Methods and Medicines; as al≈øo tho≈øe which may be brought again≈øt his particular Method and Medicine.

And fir≈øt he ≈øays, the common are of that Nature that they greatly relax the divided Fibres; ≈øo that they cannot contain the nutritive Matter brought to them, but let it pa≈øs into the Wound:
where it is by the ≈øame Medicines, corrupted and turned into Matter.

I an≈øwer; If by relaxing, he means mollifying, re≈øtoring, and reducing the Ends of the≈øe Fibres; who being irritated by the Sen≈øe of ≈øome external Injury, had convul≈øed and retired them≈øelves from their proper Situation and Offices; we ≈øhall make no great Difficulty to acknowledg it both the Effect, and ≈øome part of the De≈øign of our common Medicine.

But if by relaxing, he means the enlarging of the Fibres to a more than ordinary or convenient Widene≈øs: I an≈øwer; They have but little Tendency ≈øo to do, becau≈øe the mo≈øt part of our dige≈øtive Medicines con≈øi≈øt of con≈øiderably Re≈øtringent, Anodyne and Empla≈øtick Parts: and therefore (except very well malaxed) are not capable of in≈øinuating them≈øelves into the Fibres to that degree which is even convenient for the Exclu≈øion of
the ≈øharper part of the Air, the Admi≈ø≈øion of which is often-times the Cau≈øe of a total Ob≈øtruction.

But next, when the Matter is pa≈ø≈øed into the Wound, let us ≈øee what Power the afore≈øaid Medicine hath to bring it to Corruption; which him≈øelf ≈øays, cannot be brought to pa≈øs without a Fermentation.

We ≈øhall ≈øuppo≈øe our common Medicine to be Turpentine, and the Yolk of an Egg: Now every one knows that neither of the≈øe apart, nor both of them together, have the lea≈øt Tendency to the producing of any of the five Sorts of Fermentation; nay, (as was hinted before) they con≈øi≈øting of ≈øuch Parts, are ≈øo far from being the Cau≈øe of, that they naturally and powerfully oppo≈øe them≈øelves unto, the very lea≈øt Appearance sof it, even in the nutritive Juice it ≈øelf ≈øometimes di≈øpo≈øed that way.

Nor is there any thing more rea≈øonable, con≈øidering that the Branches of the Sulphur are at all times ready to engage, ≈øheath and detain the ≈øharppointed Acids; by which there nece≈ø≈øarily follows a Coagulation, the mo≈øt oppo≈øite Act in Nature to Fermentation.

I have one thing more to add concerning our common Medicine; and it is, that neither Tincture, Solution, nor Pouder, nor any other thing of a different Body, is either able to ≈øupply its Place, or an≈øwer its Intention in any Fle≈øh-Wound, where there is con≈øiderable lo≈øs of Sub≈øtance.

For by its analogous Sub≈øtance and Conveniency of Body, it in ≈øome mea≈øure ≈øupplies the lo≈øs of Sub≈øtance by giving a Conveniency to the Fibres to enlarge them≈øelves betwixt the Branches of its Body; and by this means not only cheri≈øheth them by its natural Warmth, but ≈øupports
their (as yet young and tender) Texture, until the Reunion be wholly perfected. An In≈øtance of which is plainly to be ≈øeen where the Application of our Medicine is continued (though never ≈øo ≈øhort while) beyond its due time, in encouraging Incarnation to a more than convenient degree.

Now ≈øince I have (as I hope) more than ≈øufficiently vindicated our Medicine, both by Experience and Rea≈øon, from tho≈øe unju≈øt A≈øper≈øions which our Antagoni≈øt hath ca≈øt upon it without either, it may not be improper to take a View of the Effects of his Medicine al≈øo in this place.
In the fir≈øt place I ≈øhall readily di≈øcharge it from the fir≈øt Particular which our Meidcine is charged with, viz. Relaxing of the Fibres, and ≈øhall make appear it only corrodes them.
Let us know, ≈øecondly, whether it corrupts the nutritive Juice by cau≈øing a Fermentation.

I am ≈øure if a corro≈øive Acid, that's ready to quarrel with even Metals them≈øelves, can contribute, it is not wanting: But if once it enter into the Ma≈øs of Blood, in≈øtead of dividing its Texture, it will go near to petrify it; and after that, there is no fear of a Fever either intermitting or continual.

I ≈øhall ≈øum up its Effects in a few words; being applied to a recent Wound, the Acid Particles immediately fix them≈øelves into the mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible Parts, cau≈øing them to retire by way of Convul≈øion as far as it is po≈ø≈øible for them, and forcing them to excern all they contain in or about their Orifices: if the fir≈øt fails, a ≈øecond Application induces an E≈øchar, except it be diluted with an extraordinary quantity of Water; and then it only keeps the Place raw, and as him≈øelf ≈øays, without any good Dige≈øtion; but if applied to a Bone,
it is infallibly condemned to a perpetual Exfoliation, as you may ≈øee in his 9th Experiment.

I have ≈øcarce any room or time now to take notice of his Complai≈øance to the Gentleman who writ that late Learned Treati≈øe of Intermitting Fevers, ≈øince he ab≈øolutely pretends to be the only competent Judg; I ≈øhall only ≈øay that he who hath the Honour of his good Opinion, is not ≈øo much obliged to him for it, as tho≈øe who have formerly treated of that Subject, are unmannerly and ignorantly cen≈øured by him.
He goes on in his 23d and 24th Pages with a deal of fal≈øe Suppo≈øitions, without the lea≈øt Pretence to either Ju≈øtice or Rea≈øon, and therefore ≈øhall receive no An≈øwer.
But now he comes to another ≈øilly ≈øuppo≈øition; the Ground of which wehave already removed, and it is this:
And if tho≈øe Hazards attend the Cure of external Fle≈øh-Wounds, what is to be expected in Wounds within the Cavity of the Body, where the Lungs, Liver, &c. are wounded?
I an≈øwer; I look upon them at lea≈øt to be mortal if they meet with no other Treatment than what either he or his Medicine is able to afford them.
He likewi≈øe ≈øays, that if any ≈øuch Accident come to be cured, the Surgeon looks upon it as a Miracle, and in no re≈øpect to be attributed either to his own Intention or Judgment.

I an≈øwer; His Mi≈øtake proceeds from his little Reading, and le≈øs Conver≈øe with Men of Sen≈øe and Experience in that Profe≈ø≈øion; any one of them being able to give him more In≈øtances of Cures of that Nature, and Rea≈øons for them, than ever he ≈øaw Wounds.
But to bring a Wound in the Lungs, Liver or Guts, &c. to Suppuration, he ≈øays, brings certain Death.

If the poor Man knew what Suppuration were, he would never harp ≈øo much upon that ≈øtring, it being no more than what him≈øelf hath frequently owned, though under another Name, viz. the bringing of the nutritious Juice to the Ends of the divided Fibres, or the ouzing out of ≈øome little Blood, or other Liquor, from their proper Ve≈ø≈øels.
But perhaps he will object, That it is not the bringing of it to the Extremities, but its pa≈ø≈øing into the Wound which he quarrels at.

I an≈øwer; To ≈øuppo≈øe that Juice or other Liquor to have been naturally accu≈øtomed to drill along the Fibres before their Divi≈øion, and now to ≈øtop exactly at the Divi≈øion, and go no further, were to allow it a greater ≈øhare of Sen≈øe, nay Rea≈øon, than him≈øelf can pretend to.

The re≈øt of the Page is not worth reading, further than to let one know
that it is ≈øo. But here comes the Difficulty in the twenty 6th Page, how to ≈øtop the Blood when a large Blood-Ve≈ø≈øel is wounded.
I an≈øwer; It mu≈øt be by other means than his Pouder; for although it be a con≈øiderable Cau≈øtick, it is not ≈øufficient for that purpo≈øe, as we ≈øhall ≈øee in the 13th Experiment, and el≈øewhere.
He is much mi≈øtaken when he ≈øays, that upon the ≈ølighte≈øt Occa≈øion we always confine our Patients to a low Diet, and let them blood: For we never do either, without apparent Rea≈øons.
In his twenty 7th he hath a notable Di≈øh of Billing≈øgate, and ought to have had Oi≈øter-Sauce e're it had been pre≈øented the King's Table.

He omits Bandages as being altogether unnece≈ø≈øary;a nd truly ≈øo they are to his Intention, except it were one to hang him≈øelf withal ≈øo ≈øoon as he is a little more fully di≈øcovered to the World.
In his twenty 9th Page he gives an Account of his Method of Cure. Which hath ≈øeveral Pieces of Rarity in it.
For Fir≈øt, It never was nor will be made u≈øe of by any other Per≈øon be≈øides him≈øelf.
Secondly, He ≈øtitches clo≈øe up all Wounds without di≈øtinction, even Gun-≈øhot Wounds them≈øelves.

The re≈øt of his Book (for want of better Stuff) is filled up with a parcel of as fal≈øe as unrea≈øonable A≈ø≈øertions, prai≈øing his own, and condemning of our Medicines; but of tho≈øe enough already.
I ≈øhall only touch a few of them as we go along, by retorting ≈øome, and laughing at others.
Fir≈øt, His external Medicine cau≈øes exce≈ø≈øive Pain when fir≈øt applied.
Secondly, There is always a con≈øiderable deal of Pain afterwards, and the Parts ≈øo ≈øtiff and ≈øore, as if they never would be well.

Thirdly, If there hath been no Pain at all before, it never fails in a few Moments after the Application to bring a troop of ill Symptoms upon the Part; ≈øuch as Swellings, Inflammodons, &c. which (by the way) is a ≈øure Argument that it is a ≈øharp Medicine, and a Cau≈øtick, though he deny it.

Fourthly, His Medicine hath always a Fever for its Companion: for ≈øeveral People who have been wounded, and by our Medicine brought to a fair way of Recovery, have in a very ≈ømall time by the u≈øe of his Medicine been thrown into Fevers, accompanied with violent Pains in the Parts.

And again; The ≈øame Per≈øons by quitting of his Method and Medicine, and u≈øing of ours, have been as ≈øuddenly recovered: As may be ≈øeen in our 15th Remark. The fifth being only a Repetition, I ≈øhall take no notice of it.

In his thirty 4th Page he makes and an≈øwers a terrible Objection, viz. How it's po≈ø≈øible for him, without bringing a Wound to Suppuration, to obtain the Di≈øcharge of extraneous Bodies; ≈øuch as Bullets, Clothes, Splinters, &c.

I ≈øhall ≈øoon an≈øwer that for him: He hath in his Method of Cure ≈øtitched them all hard up long ago, for fear they ≈øhould have been kept open by tenting. Pa≈ø≈øing his other Repetitions, we come to his In≈øtance in the thirty 6th Page of two Officers of the Fu≈øileers; the Matter of Fact to my certain Knowledg was thus:

Lieutenant Fletcher, the Subject of hsi 4th Experiment, being one of them, we ≈øhall refer him to the Remark upon that Experiment; the other was wounded with a hollow Blade, the Point entred a little above the Carpus, or Wri≈øt, on the under and in≈øide; ≈øo pa≈ø≈øing under the Artery,
and rubbing upon ≈øeveral of the Tendons and Radius, came out about five or ≈øix Inches upwards from its Entrance.

The≈øe two Gentlemen were wounded at one time; and although the Doctor is plea≈øed to ≈øhew his Judgment in ≈øaying the latter was ≈ølightly wounded, he will neverthele≈øs to any unprejudiced Per≈øon plainly appear to have been more dangerou≈øly wounded than the other: He was dre≈ø≈øed by the Surgeon to the Regiment; and although about the fourteenth Day there came a Swelling, and ≈øome Inflammation upon the Part, and that by the Gentleman's owned Neglect, yet that was in le≈øs than twenty four Hours removed, and the Gentleman (whatever the Doctor fal≈øly and maliciou≈øly reports to the contrary) was in le≈øs than three Weeks perfectly well.

He goes on in the thirty 7th and thirty 8th Pages with the already thread-bare Encomiums of his Medicine; and after a needle≈øs Caution, forbidding us to believe that he can work Miracles, he refers us for the Proof of all to the fourteen following SExperiments; which are to him like Samp≈øon's Locks: but I ≈øuppo≈øe with this Difference, that if once they be cut off, they are never like to grow again.

Although ≈øome part of the following Experiments have been hitherto Stranger to my Ears, (though always upon the Place where they pretend to have been acted) I ≈øhall not therefore conclude that there never were ≈øuch Per≈øon in being as the Subjects of them: neverthele≈øs, I may (I hope) without breach of either Mode≈øty or Charity, be bold to affirm, (and that uupon good Grounds) that the Matter of Fact in all of them
is very much different from that Relation the Learned Author is here plea≈øed to make us: For,

Fir≈øt, Such of his Experiments which either my own Eyes, or tho≈øe of my unque≈øtionable Evidences have been Witne≈ø≈øes to, are as far from being true as rea≈øonable; as we ≈øhall ≈øee in their proper place.

Secondly, The Names of, and his Experiments upon all Per≈øons who have mi≈øcarried under his hand, (e≈øpecially ≈øuch as every one may ea≈øily inform them≈øelves of the Truth of) are by him utterly ≈øuppre≈øs'd and conceal'd.
Thirdly, The Improbability, nay Impo≈ø≈øibility, which attends the greate≈øt part of his Relations mu≈øt needs be no ≈ømall Impediment to their Credit, with any con≈øiderate and judicious Per≈øon.

Neverthele≈øs, I ≈øhall not any where in my Remarks upon his following
Experiments, contradict his pretended Matter of Fact, excepting ≈øuch as I am able to bring undoubted Proof to the contrary.
For the re≈øt, I ≈øhall only (en pa≈ø≈øant) ob≈øerve ≈øome few of his many as well Improbabilities as Incon≈øi≈øtencies.

div.head: Remarks upon his Fir≈øt Experiement.
div.p:
THis Experiment tells us of a Per≈øon run through the Left-arm, and into the Lungs: The Per≈øon ≈øays he found the Sword pa≈øs into the very inmo≈øt part of his Brea≈øt; and I am ≈øure the Doctor was obliged to take his word, ≈øince he will not allow Sounding by Probe. By its entring betwixt the ≈øecond and third Rib, I hope he reckons upwards; and then in≈øtead of the Lungs, the Guts lay next to hand: But ≈øuppo≈øe the wor≈øt; he
walked that very Day ≈øix Miles (I hope he means Flemi≈øh) on foot with the Army, without being in the lea≈øt di≈øordred; Si credere fas ≈øit.

div.head: Remarks upon his Second Experiment.
div.p: HEre is a Relation which I have heard far otherwi≈øt from ≈øeveral Gentlemen of that Regiment; but ≈øuppo≈øe the Matter of Fact true, I do not find it any the lea≈øt of kin to a Miracle.
The Per≈øon was, as he ≈øays, run into the Belly about two Inches above the Navel on the right-≈øide; the Sword, as him≈øelf, and other Spectators ≈øay, entred at lea≈øt ≈øeven or eight Inches.

I mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that both the Per≈øon him≈øelf, and the Spectators too, had either a deal of pre≈øence of Mind, or good Mathematical Eyes; otherwi≈øe the Per≈øon who made the Thru≈øt was ≈øo deliberate in the Action,
as would ea≈øily have proved premeditated Malice, had he been tried at the Old Bailey.
He ≈øays he believes the Symptoms that attended him, do plainly demon≈øtrate that both Liver and Inte≈øtines were wounded: But for my part, I do not.

For neither Vomiting, nor Pain in his Belly, nor Re≈øtle≈øne≈øs, nor even the Stooling of bloody Excrement, (which are all the Symptoms him≈øelf gives) are ≈øufficient to demon≈øtrate the Inte≈øtines to be wounded; the la≈øt oftner proceeding from Brui≈øs, &c. than any thing el≈øe. However, by the U≈øe of the Pouder and Tiucture, he was pre≈øently well; and indeed who would not work a little Miracle when their whole Reputation lies at ≈øtake?

div.head: Remarks upon his Third Experiment.
div.p: WE are now come to that Experiment which gave ri≈øe (though under≈øervedly) to all its Author's Reputation, and that more by the Ignorance, or at lea≈øt Inadvertency of ≈øome other Surgeons, than either his own Ingenuity or Conduct.

The Matter of Fact is; The Per≈øon of the ≈øame Name and Regiment which he relates, was run into the Brea≈øt: the Surgeon to the Regiment ≈øounding of the Wound with his Probe, and being alarmed with the rebutting of it by the Sy≈øtole and Dia≈øtole of the Heart, did thence ra≈øhly and incon≈øiderately conclude that the Wound mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily penetrate into the Cavity; never con≈øidering that even the laying of a Probe (or the like) upon the Region of the Heart (though without the Skin)
will give it a con≈øiderable Motion; but much more if thru≈øt into, or pre≈ø≈øed upon its more contiguous Mu≈øcles. The Surgeon (as is ≈øaid) being ≈øurprized, gave the Standers-by but little hopes of his Life; whereupon our Doctor was ≈øent for, and I do believe cured him, thugh not in ≈øo ≈øhort time as he relates.

For I am very well a≈ø≈øured by two credible Per≈øons, that the Cure was no le≈øs than ≈øix Weeks long; which is more than thrice the time it needed, con≈øidering it neither pentrated, nor was accompained with any con≈øiderable Hemorogy of Blood: As for ≈øuch a Number of Surgeons coming and pulling off his Dre≈ø≈øings, the Per≈øon him≈øelf will not own.

div.head: Remarks upon his Fourth Experiment.
div.p: IT ≈øeems the Author was afraid of coming ≈øhort in the Number of his Experiments, otherwi≈øe he would never have in≈øerted this among≈øt his Miracles, being no more than a Wound with a Sword in the fle≈øhy part of the Thigh; and although I have ≈øpoke with ≈øeveral Per≈øons that ≈øaw it, I cannot find it to have been half ≈øo large as he reports: But ≈øuppo≈øe it were, that could but little retard the Cure, ≈øince neither Blood-Ve≈ø≈øel nor Tendon was wounded. He does well in a≈ø≈øigning no definite time for the Cure; becau≈øe the Gentleman at that time was obliged to go to the Gari≈øon e're that was effected, and (as I can make appear) was not fit to come to Camp for ≈øeveral Months after.

div.head: Remarks upon his Fifth Experiment.
div.p: THis Experiment gives account of a Per≈øon wounded in the Stomach with a Sword; but his Medicines being u≈øed according to the u≈øual Method, immediately removed all the Symptoms; and among≈øt others his Convul≈øions, which were very great, were, ictu oculi, by the U≈øe of his Tincture, taken away; which (by the way) is no ≈ømall Wonder: For to my certain Knowledg that very Tincture hath at other times brought Convul≈øions even unto Death, upon Per≈øons who otherwi≈øe had no Tendency that way; as we ≈øhall ≈øee in the Ca≈øe of Capt. Rogers, &c. neverthele≈øs it cured him, and ≈øo we leave him.

div.head: Remarks upon his Sixth Experiment.
div.p: HEre we are told of a Per≈øon who had his Sternum, or Brea≈øtbone divided with a Sword; but whither according to its Length or Breadth, we have no Account: However, the Sword pa≈ø≈øed on into the Lungs (as he ≈øays); but it ≈øeems 'twas lent with Mr. Chomley, for he was not ≈øtrong enough to keep on the Dre≈ø≈øings again≈øt ≈øuch violent Eruptions of Blood and Air. Here is a new Mode of Stitching, the which is hardly reconcilable; and more than that, here is a ≈ømall Mi≈øtake in the Relation of Matter of Fa≈øt: For,
Fir≈øt, The Lungs were not touch'd, nor could we find any certain Sign that ever the Wound had penetrated.

And, Secondly, he was ≈øo far from being recovered when he come to the Ho≈øpital, that had he not thet with
better Treatment there than he did from him, he had never recovered.

div.head: Remarks upon his Seventh Experiment.
div.p: HEre is another Per≈øon wounded in the Lungs, and given over for dead by ≈øeveral Surgeons; his Wound had been a Fortnight received, and he in a very bad Condition: neverthele≈øs by twice applying his Pouder, he was cured. By which, I perceive that his Pouder mends upon his hand; for formerly it u≈øed to work no Wonders, except it were fir≈øt applied: However, (to the be≈øt of my Remembrance) I was told of this Accident by the Surgeon to the Regiment, that not with ≈øtanding his U≈øe of both Pouder and Tincture, and even that of more effectual Medicines, the Per≈øon was never like to be well.

div.head: Remarks upon his Eighth Experiment.
div.p:
WE are here told of a forth Per≈øon wounded in the Lungs; which in my Opinion is not a little ≈øtrange, that among≈øt fourteen Accidents four of them ≈øhould be upon the Lungs; though I can affirm that I have ≈øeen five hundred at one time wounded, and not ≈øo many among them all: But perhaps the≈øe have been ≈øent by ≈øome ≈øpecial piece of Providence for the trial of his Experiments, although I am apter to believe that with him all Wounds in the Brea≈øt are judged to be in the Lungs; and indeed he is in ≈øome mea≈øure excu≈øable, ≈øince he works by gue≈øs, and finds it again≈øt his Con≈øcience to allow of Sounding: nor is there here any cleare Symptoms of this Per≈øon's being wounded in the Lungs; his ≈øpitting of Blood and Shortne≈øs of Breath being
more applicable to his former Cough than his pre≈øent Wound. But he is pretty mode≈øt here in a≈ø≈øigning him no determinate time for his Cure.

div.head: Remarks upon his Ninth Experiment.
div.p: WE come now to the Wonder of the whole Book: A Per≈øon ≈øhot with a Bullet through the back part of his Hand, and the Bones of the Metacarp all ≈øhattered, and Tendons much torn; and yet by ≈øome few Applications of his Pouder, he was ≈øoon cured.

I ≈øhould be unpardonable if I ≈øuffered the World to be impo≈øed upon in this and the following Experiment, having been Eye-witne≈øs to the whole Matter of Fact in both: this pre≈øent was thus: One John Wyles in the Regiment of the Honourable Lord George Hamilton, in the Company of Capt. Hay's, was upon the twenty fir≈øt of July Old Stile, ≈øher in the Back of
the Hand; the Bullet entred betwixt that Bone of the Metacarp which ≈øu≈øtains the Middle and that which ≈øu≈øtains the Ring-finger, gra≈øing upon the latter as it entred, broke the former, and in coming out rubb'd upon that which ≈øu≈øtains the Fore-finger. I went with one of his Officers to ≈øee him next Morning; and he told me he had been dre≈ø≈øed, but complained of intolerable Pain: Three days after I made him another vi≈øit, but he had not then been dre≈ø≈øed a ≈øecond time. However, the fir≈øt had ≈øo ting'd the Bandage, and every thing el≈øe about it, that it was no hard matter to conclude it a Vitriolike Medicine. I ≈øaw it ≈øeveral times after wards, but always the ≈øame colour, and a perpetual Flux of crude undige≈øted Matter coming from it: When I ≈øaw it about a Fortnight after, both Orifices were much contracted, and ≈øome little ≈øpungy Excre≈øcences in the Form of
≈ømall Bramble-berries, ≈øhewing them≈øelves about its Circumference, with ≈øtill the ≈øame quantity and ≈øort of Matter; and the Patient always complaining of intolerable Pains after dre≈ø≈øing, which had then been performed four times; and then the Hand began to ≈øwell con≈øiderably.

I vi≈øited him again the Twentieth of Augu≈øt, with the Chaplain to the Regiment and ≈øeveral others: I then found his Hand prodigiou≈øly ≈øwelled ≈øo, that he could not ≈øo much as move one of his Fingers. I asked him how he found it? He an≈øwered me very well, to my no ≈ømall Admiration: But looking about, and ≈øeeing ≈øome of his Tent-mates, I asked them if he was not di≈øtracted? But they (laughing) told me, that e're I came the Doctor had been there, and given him two Shillings upon Condition he ≈øhould make that An≈øwer to any one who ≈øhould ask him how he did. The
Per≈øon him≈øelf being taxed with it, could not deny it; but this he did al≈øo to his Comerade in the next Experiment, and ≈øeveral others.

This was at the Camp at Winingham, and after the long March which he mentions; neither had it at that time di≈øcharged any of that va≈øt number of Bones which him≈øelf ≈øays it di≈øcharged afterwards, nor do I believe 'tis well to this day.

div.head: Remarks upon his Tenth Experiment.
div.p:
ANdrew Chri≈øty, in the ≈øame Regiment and Company, was wounded at the ≈øame time with the former. For the mo≈øt part I vi≈øited them both together: He was ≈øhot with a Brace of Bullets; one of them grazed, but very ≈øuperficially, betwixt two of his Ribs; the other after having grazed a little way lodged, but very ≈øuperficially al≈øo. This,
as the other always, complained of exce≈ø≈øive Pain. After Dre≈ø≈øing (as him≈øelf ≈øays) they always di≈øcharged a great quantity of ≈øerous Matter. I vi≈øited him the Fourth of Augu≈øt, Old Stile, and took al≈øo ≈øeveral others along with me; when he not only complained of exce≈ø≈øive Pains in that Side, but likewi≈øe over all the re≈øt of his Body; was very feveri≈øh: and I am fully ≈øatisfied (although the Doctor ≈øays he was but three Weeks under Cure) that he was above a Month from that time.

div.head: Remarks upon his Eleventh, Twelfth, and Fourteenth Experiments.
div.p:
THe≈øe three Experiments I confe≈øs I am altogether a Stranger to; but if there be either any ≈øuch Per≈øons or matter of Fact, I ≈øhall in a very little time be able to give a full and unque≈øtionable Account of
them, and they ≈øhall be publi≈øhed by way of Adverti≈øements, either in the Gazette or el≈øewhere: However, ≈øuppo≈øe his own Relation to be in all Points true, (which I do believe is more than any rea≈øonable Per≈øon will do, con≈øidering the re≈øt have been generally fal≈øe) I have known far greater Cures done with le≈øs than half the noi≈øe.

div.head: Remarks upon his Thirteenth Experiment.
div.p: THe Maker has got as little Reputation by this Experiment, as he hath u≈øed Truth in the Relation of it.

The Gentlemans Name was Lorring, in the Honourable Brigadeer Lumley's Regiment: He ≈øays he received a ≈ølight Wound under the right Arm-pit, the Axillary Artery being al≈øo prick'd, upon which en≈øued a large Flux of Blood.
A notable piece of Incon≈øi≈øtency; a ≈ølight Wound, and yet the Axillary Artery pricked.
He ≈øays the Blood was ≈øoon ≈øtop'd, or rather pent in by Mr. Engli≈øh Surgeon to the Regiment; however, it was more than he could do afterwards, by all his big Preten≈øions.

'Tis true, that after ≈øome time there happened a fre≈øh Flux of Blood, which was the Occa≈øion that he was called, but (at lea≈øt) mi≈øtakes when he ≈øays they u≈øed red hot irons to ≈øtop it; though I do believe they had better done it, than tru≈øted to his Pouder, as they did to the (at lea≈øt) anticipating their Patient's De≈øtruction.

His Arm was but little ≈øwell'd, and not at all mortified; nor did he lo≈øt (before that time) one ≈øixth part of the Blood which he mentions. When he came fir≈øt to the Patient, he was asked by Mr. Hall, whether
